title: 110_s2471
content: The "USERRA Enforcement Improvement Act of 2007" is the short title of this Act. It aims to reform the USERRA complaint process. The subsection (c) of section 4322 of title 38, United States Code, is amended to ensure that the Secretary notifies a complainant of their rights within 5 days of receiving a complaint. The Secretary is also required to provide technical assistance to the complainant and their employer upon request. The Secretary must resolve complaints within 90 days of receipt under subsections (d) and (e) of section 4322. Referrals to the attorney general must be expedited under section 4323(a)(1) of title 38, United States Code. The Secretary must refer complaints to the Attorney General within 15 days of receiving a request. Referrals to special counsel must also be expedited within the same timeframe. The Attorney General must make a decision within 45 days of receiving a referral and notify the person involved. Special counsel notifications are also required to be expedited within the same timeframe. The Special Counsel must make a decision within 45 days of receiving a referral and notify the person involved. Expansion of reporting requirements for USERRA enforcement. Modification of Annual Report by Secretary under title 38, United States Code includes adding new paragraphs regarding cases reviewed by the Secretary of Defense through the National Committee for Employer Support of the Guard and Reserve. The Secretary of Defense, through the National Committee for Employer Support of the Guard and Reserve, reviews cases involving employment or reemployment of the same person. The cases reported include those related to disabilities. The Secretary of Defense reviews cases involving employment or reemployment of individuals with disabilities and reports the number of cases for each type of disability to Congress and other relevant authorities. The Comptroller General of the United States will provide quarterly reports to Congress, the Secretary of Defense, the Secretary of Veterans Affairs, the Attorney General, and the Special Counsel on cases where the Secretary did not meet certain requirements. The Comptroller General will report quarterly to Congress, the Secretary of Defense, the Secretary of Veterans Affairs, the Attorney General, and the Special Counsel on cases where referrals were not made within the required time periods. The Special Counsel received referrals under section 4323(a) and 4324(a) but did not meet the requirements for those referrals. The Secretary will coordinate with the Secretary of Defense and the Secretary of Veterans Affairs for uniform categorization of data. The Secretary will coordinate with the Secretary of Defense, the Secretary of Veterans Affairs, the Attorney General, and the Special Counsel to ensure uniform categorization of information in reports and electronic access to case files. Effective Date: The amendments apply to reports required under section 4332. The amendments apply to reports required under section 4332 after the enactment of this Act.
